It is true that some sports apparel brands have been accused of continuing to use hazardous chemicals in their products despite their commitments to eliminate them. This can be a difficult issue to track, as supply chains can be complex and brands may not have full visibility into every step of the production process.

However, there are a few ways that consumers and advocacy groups can hold brands accountable for their commitments to reduce the use of hazardous chemicals:

1. Look for independent certifications: Many third-party organizations offer certification programs for brands that demonstrate adherence to strict chemical management and sustainability standards. Look for products that are certified by organizations such as the Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS), Bluesign, or the Cradle to Cradle program.

2. Check company reports: Many brands publish annual sustainability reports that detail their progress towards their environmental and social responsibility goals. Look for information on chemical management and transparency in the company's supply chain, and look for any red flags or areas of concern that the company acknowledges.

3. Join or support advocacy groups: There are many advocacy groups working to promote sustainable and ethical practices in the fashion industry, and they can be a valuable resource for consumers who want to hold brands accountable for their environmental and social impacts. Supporting these groups through donations or activism can help to push for change in the industry.

Overall, while it can be challenging to ensure that sports apparel brands are following through on their promises to reduce the use of hazardous chemicals, there are steps that consumers and advocacy groups can take to hold them accountable and promote positive change in the industry.
